Under international pressure, elections were finally scheduled for December 2018.  Kabila himself did not run again, and his chosen successor Emmanuel Ramazani Shadary lost the election to Félix Tshisekedi, who assumed the presidency in January 2019. 

After the end of his presidency, Joseph Kabila remains an influential figure in the DRC, and his political legacy continues to be the subject of ongoing debates and assessments.
Jakaya Kikwete:
Jakaya Mrisho Kikwete is a Tanzanian politician who served as the fourth President of the United Republic of Tanzania from 2005 to 2015.  Here is a brief biography with information about his early life, political career, and achievements. 

**Early Life and Education:**
Jakaya Kikwete was born on October 7, 1950 in Msoga, Tanzania.  He attended primary school in his hometown and continued his education at Kibaha Secondary School.  He then went to Tanga Secondary School, where he received his O-Level education.  Kikwete completed his A-Level education at Kibaha High School. 

He studied at the University of Dar es Salaam and obtained a bachelor's degree in economics.  During his studies, Kikwete was active in student politics and discovered his passion for public service. 

**Military Service:**
After graduation, Kikwete joined the Tanzanian armed forces and rose to the rank of lieutenant.  During his service, he underwent various military trainings, both in Tanzania and internationally. 

**Political Career:**
Kikwete began his political career in the 1980s, holding various political positions in the government and the Revolutionary State Party Chama Cha Mapinduzi (CCM), which has been the dominant political party in Tanzania since the country's independence. 

In 1988, he was elected as a member of the Central Committee and the National Executive Committee of the CCM.  He also served as a minister in various government departments, including finance, energy and minerals, water, energy and natural resources, as well as foreign affairs. 

In 1995, Kikwete was elected as a Member of Parliament for the Bagamoyo constituency, and from 2000 he served as Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation under President Benjamin Mkapa. 

**Presidency:**
In December 2005, after a successful election campaign as the CCM candidate for the presidency, Kikwete was elected as the fourth President of Tanzania.  He succeeded Benjamin Mkapa and won the election with a significant majority.  During his tenure, Kikwete focused on economic reforms, improving infrastructure, doubling efforts to combat HIV/AIDS and malaria, and enhancing education systems. 

In 2010, he was re-elected for a second term and continued his efforts to improve living conditions in Tanzania.  Under his leadership, the country achieved solid economic growth, and there were improvements in the provision of public services, particularly in the health and education sectors. 

**Life after the Presidency:**
After the end of his presidency in 2015, Kikwete continued to engage in various international and regional initiatives.  He has focused particularly on issues such as development, peace, and security in Africa.  In recognition of his contributions, he became active in several forums and organizations, advocating for the protection of women and children, among other causes. 

Jakaya Kikwete has received numerous awards and honorary doctorates during and after his presidency, recognizing his contributions to Tanzania and the African continent.
Jacob Zuma:
Jacob Gedleyihlekisa Zuma is a former President of South Africa, who served from 2009 to 2018.  He was born on April 12, 1942 in Nkandla, KwaZulu-Natal, as the son of a policeman and a housewife.  Zuma did not receive formal education and grew up in poverty.  Nevertheless, he managed to rise to become one of the most well-known political leaders in South Africa. 

Zuma's political career began when he joined the African National Congress (ANC) during the apartheid in the late 1950s.  He became an active member of the ANC Youth League and rose within the organization.  In 1963, Zuma was arrested during anti-apartheid activities and sentenced to 10 years in prison on the infamous Robben Island, where Nelson Mandela was also imprisoned. 

After his release in 1973, Zuma worked for the ANC underground and lived in exile in several African countries.  During this time, he established relationships with other anti-apartheid activists and military personnel.  Following the legalization of the ANC in 1990, Zuma returned to South Africa and was elected as head of the ANC intelligence services. 

His political star continued to rise when in 1994, after the first democratic elections in South Africa, President Nelson Mandela appointed Zuma as a member of the executive committee of the KwaZulu-Natal province.  Under Thabo Mbeki, Zuma served as deputy president before being dismissed in 2005 due to corruption allegations.  Despite these accusations, he was elected President of the ANC in 2007. 

In 2009, Jacob Zuma was elected President of South Africa.  His tenure was marked by controversies, including further corruption allegations, especially related to a multimillion-dollar upgrade project of his private residence in Nkandla, largely funded with state resources.  Furthermore, his presidency was accompanied by economic challenges and growing public dissatisfaction. 

In February 2018, Jacob Zuma resigned under intense pressure from his own party.  He left behind a mixed legacy, characterized by his contributions to the liberation struggle against apartheid, but overshadowed by corruption scandals and allegations of mismanagement. 

After his resignation, Zuma remained a controversial figure in South African politics.  He has repeatedly denied accusations of financial misconduct and unethical behavior, claiming to be the target of political conspiracies.  His trial and related legal battles continue to impact the political landscape of South Africa at the time of this writing.
Uhuru Kenyatta:
Uhuru Muigai Kenyatta was born on October 26, 1961, and is a Kenyan politician who served as the fourth President of the Republic of Kenya from April 2013 to September 2022.  As the son of Jomo Kenyatta, the first President of Kenya, Uhuru was born into a great political legacy.  His name "Uhuru" means "freedom" in Swahili, a symbolic name reflecting the era of independence. 

Uhuru Kenyatta was born into a privileged family in Nairobi and grew up in the political environment of his father.  After studying in Kenya, he went to Amherst College in the United States to study economics. 

After entering the Kenyan business world, Kenyatta began his political career in 1997 when he successfully ran for a seat in Parliament.  He held various positions, including leading the Ministry of Local Government and later serving as Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance. 

In 2002, Uhuru Kenyatta was selected by President Daniel arap Moi as the successor candidate for the Kenya African National Union (KANU), but he lost the presidential election to Mwai Kibaki.  He then served as the opposition leader, focusing on reorganizing KANU and solidifying his own political base. 

His rise to power came in 2013 when he won the presidential elections as the candidate of the newly formed Jubilee Alliance party.  His presidency was controversial from the start as he and his deputy William Ruto were charged by the International Criminal Court (ICC) with alleged crimes against humanity following the disputed 2007 elections.  The charges were later dropped due to lack of evidence. 

During his time as President, Kenyatta focused on infrastructure development, strengthening education and healthcare, and investing in technology and innovation.  He also promoted a series of major projects known as the "Big Four" to improve housing, manufacturing, healthcare, and food security.  His term was also marked by challenges including corruption scandals, ethnic tensions, and allegations of election manipulation during the 2017 elections. 

Despite the controversies, Kenyatta's presidency is often associated with economic growth and progress in various sectors.  After completing his second term in office in 2022, he left behind a complex legacy of progress and challenges for Kenya.
Yoweri Museveni:
Yoweri Kaguta Museveni is a Ugandan politician who has been the President of Uganda since 1986.  He was born on August 15, 1944 in the Ntungamo District in Uganda's former British East Africa protectorate. 

Museveni attended Kyamate Elementary School, Mbarara High School, and later Ntare School.  He then studied at the University of Dar es Salaam in Tanzania, where he obtained a bachelor's degree in Economics and Political Science.  During his studies, Museveni became politically active and joined the leftist União Nacional Africana de Moçambique (now FRELIMO) to fight against the colonial regime in Mozambique. 

After completing his studies, Museveni returned to Uganda to fight against the government of Idi Amin, who ruled the country with an iron fist from 1971 to 1979.  Over the years, Museveni participated in various resistance movements and eventually founded the National Resistance Army (NRA), which fought against the subsequent governments of Milton Obote and Tito Okello, both of whom came to power through military coups. 

In January 1986, the NRA finally captured the capital city of Kampala, and Museveni became the President of Uganda.  As President, he became known for his efforts to reduce ethnic tensions, liberalize the economy, and advance the fight against HIV/AIDS, gaining international recognition.  Under Museveni, Uganda experienced economic growth and relative stability compared to the turbulent decades before. 

Nevertheless, Museveni's presidency has also been marked by controversies and criticism, particularly regarding human rights abuses, suppression of the opposition, and the elimination of presidential term limits, which allowed him to run for reelection multiple times.  His reelection campaigns were often overshadowed by allegations of election manipulation and political violence. 

During his presidency, Museveni has also played a key role in regional conflicts and peace initiatives.  Ugandan troops have been involved in various military interventions in the region, including conflicts in South Sudan and the Democratic Republic of the Congo. 

Despite international criticism and domestic opposition, Museveni is a central figure in Uganda's modern history and remains a controversial but dominant figure in the country's politics.
Abdelaziz Bouteflika:
Abdelaziz Bouteflika was an Algerian statesman and politician who served as President of Algeria from 1999 until his resignation in April 2019.  Bouteflika was born on March 2, 1937, in Oujda in what was then French-ruled Morocco and grew up during a time when Algeria was striving for independence from French colonial rule. 

At the age of 19, Bouteflika joined the National Liberation Front (FLN), which was fighting for Algeria's independence.  After the independence was won in 1962, Bouteflika held various political positions, including Minister of Youth and Sports, and later Minister of Foreign Affairs under President Houari Boumediene.  As Foreign Minister, a position he held from 1963 to 1979, Bouteflika played a central role in strengthening Algeria's position on the international stage, including its membership in the Non-Aligned Movement. 

Following Boumediene's death in 1978 and subsequent political changes, Bouteflika withdrew from Algerian politics and spent many years abroad.  In the 1980s, he was convicted in absentia on corruption charges, but he returned to politics in the 1990s as Algeria experienced a period of civil war and political instability. 

Bouteflika was elected President in 1999 after his six opponents withdrew from the election, paving the way for his victory.  As President, Bouteflika focused on stabilizing the country and improving the conditions devastated by the civil war.  He initiated a reconciliation process and offered amnesty to militant fighters, leading to a significant reduction in violence. 

He was reelected in 2004, 2009, and 2014 for additional terms, although allegations of election fraud and criticism of his governance persisted.  The 2019 elections and Bouteflika's intention to run for a fifth term sparked massive protests as part of the "Hirak" movement.  Bouteflika faced significant pressure from both the population and key institutions such as the military, and eventually resigned in April 2019. 

His presidency has been criticized by critics for political stagnation, corruption, and authoritarian tendencies.  At the same time, supporters praise his role in achieving peace and stability after the dark chapter of the civil war. 

After his resignation, Abdelaziz Bouteflika retreated from the public eye and passed away on September 17, 2021.  His legacy remains controversial in Algeria.
Omar al-Bashir:
Omar Hassan Ahmad al-Bashir was born on January 1, 1944 in Hosh Bannaga, Sudan.  He comes from an Arab farming family of the Ja'alin ethnic group and joined the Sudanese army at a young age.  His military career was the beginning of a long journey that ultimately led him to the top of the Sudanese state. 

In 1960, al-Bashir graduated from the military academy and was later sent abroad for various training programs, including in Egypt and Malaysia.  He rose through the military ranks and gained considerable respect within the army. 

On June 30, 1989, Omar al-Bashir, then a brigadier general, led a bloodless military coup that overthrew the democratically elected government led by Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi.  He justified this by claiming that he aimed to end the political instability and the associated deterioration of the country's economy.  As a result, he suspended the constitution, dissolved the parliament and cabinet, and declared a state of emergency.  He appointed himself as the chairman of the Revolutionary Command Council for National Salvation (RCC), which became the highest governing and legislative body in the country. 

During his tenure, al-Bashir established an Islamic-oriented government and was repeatedly elected as president, although the elections were often overshadowed by irregularities and allegations of manipulation.  He governed Sudan through several periods of emergency and frequently repressed political opposition movements brutally. 

One of the darkest chapters of al-Bashir's presidency was the conflict in Darfur, which began in 2003.  International human rights organizations accused his government of committing serious human rights abuses and war crimes.  The International Criminal Court (ICC) in The Hague issued an arrest warrant against him in 2009 on suspicion of genocide, crimes against humanity, and war crimes in Darfur.  He became the first sitting president against whom the ICC issued such a warrant. 

Despite international isolation, al-Bashir continued to travel abroad, even though many countries were obligated to arrest and extradite him to the ICC. 

After nearly 30 years in power, Omar al-Bashir was ousted in April 2019 through a military coup in response to months of protests against his government.  The protests were sparked by a rapidly deteriorating economy, corruption, and government inefficiency. 

After his ousting, al-Bashir was detained, and the military established a transitional council to lead Sudan into a new era.  In December 2019, a Sudanese court sentenced al-Bashir to two years of house arrest for corruption and money laundering, as they did not want to send him to a regular prison due to his advanced age. 

Al-Bashir's fall from the presidency marks a turning point in modern Sudanese history, as the country continues to struggle for democratization and stability.
Abdelilah Benkirane:
Abdelilah Benkirane is a Moroccan politician, best known as the former Prime Minister of Morocco.  He was born on April 2, 1954 in Fès, Morocco, and comes from a family background.  Throughout his life, Benkirane has established himself as a key player on Morocco's political stage. 

Education and Early Career:
Benkirane began his studies at Mohammed V University in Rabat, where he specialized in Islamic law.  He started his political career in the 1970s, getting involved in Islamist movements.  He was a co-founder of the "Islamic Youth," which later laid the foundation for the development of the Party of Justice and Development (PJD). 

Political Career:
Benkirane joined the Movement for Unity and Reform (MUR), which later evolved into the PJD, a moderate Islamist political party advocating for Islam and democracy.  Due to his dedication and beliefs, he rose within the party. 

Before his appointment as Prime Minister, Benkirane served as the chairman of the PJD.  His political approach focused on combining moderate Islamist ideas with pragmatic policies to address social and economic issues. 

Prime Minister:
Following the parliamentary elections in November 2011, held in the wake of the "Arab Spring" where the PJD emerged as the strongest force, Abdelilah Benkirane was appointed as the Prime Minister of Morocco by King Mohammed VI.  He formed a coalition government and led the cabinet until 2016. 

During his tenure as Prime Minister, Benkirane implemented some significant reforms.  His government reduced subsidies, reformed the pension system, and introduced a series of economic policy changes to reduce the budget deficit and stabilize the Moroccan economy. 

After the parliamentary elections in October 2016, Benkirane was tasked with forming a new government but was unable to establish a coalition.  In March 2017, he was replaced as the designated Prime Minister by Saadeddine Othmani, also a member of the PJD. 

Personal Life:
Benkirane is known for his direct communication style and close connection with the people.  He is married and a father of six children.  In his free time, he enjoys writing poetry and is a follower of the Sufi branch within Islam. 

Significance:
As the leader of the PJD and as Prime Minister, Abdelilah Benkirane played a key role during a phase when Morocco was experiencing political and social change due to the events of the Arab Spring.  He is considered one of the individuals who significantly contributed to integrating Islamist ideas into Morocco's multiparty democratic process.
Jos\u00e9 Eduardo dos Santos:
José Eduardo dos Santos was born on August 28, 1942 in Luanda, the capital of Angola.  He was a prominent Angolan politician and served as President of Angola from 1979 to 2017.  His long tenure made him one of the longest-serving heads of state in Africa. 

Dos Santos was born during the time of Portuguese colonial rule and joined the resistance against this rule at an early age.  In 1961, he joined the People's Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA), a Marxist-oriented liberation movement that fought against Portuguese colonial rule.  His political activism led dos Santos to go abroad to avoid reprisals.  He studied engineering in Azerbaijan, then part of the Soviet Union, and returned to Angola in the 1970s. 

After gaining independence from Portugal in 1975, the Angolan Civil War broke out.  The MPLA, led by Agostinho Neto, took control of the government, while rival liberation movements, supported by international actors such as the apartheid regime of South Africa and the United States, fought against them. 

When Neto died in 1979, dos Santos took over the leadership of the MPLA and thus the presidency of Angola.  His time in office was marked by the long and devastating civil war that lasted until 2002.  During his rule, dos Santos systematically expanded his power and established centralized control over the country. 

Under his leadership, Angola used its abundant oil and diamond resources to strengthen the economy and finance the country's reconstruction after the civil war.  However, his government and family were repeatedly criticized and accused of corruption, nepotism, and abuse of wealth. 

José Eduardo dos Santos was seen as a skilled political tactician who often relied on the support of the military and state oil and diamond companies.  Although under his leadership the MPLA was able to retain power and transition from a Marxist-Leninist party to essentially a capitalist party, Angola's political scene remained relatively non-pluralistic until his resignation. 

In August 2017, after 38 years as president, dos Santos resigned and handed over power to his chosen successor, João Lourenço.  His resignation marked the end of an era in Angolan politics, with his legacy continuing to be controversially debated, especially in terms of political stability, economic development, and human rights record in Angola.  José Eduardo dos Santos died on July 8, 2022 in Barcelona, Spain, where he was undergoing medical treatment.
Filipe Nyusi:
Filipe Jacinto Nyusi is a Mozambican politician who has been serving as the President of Mozambique since January 15, 2015.  He is a member of the Frelimo party (Frente de Libertação de Moçambique), which has dominated the country's political scene since independence in 1975. 

Filipe Nyusi was born on February 9, 1959 in the province of Cabo Delgado in northern Mozambique.  He grew up during a time of political unrest as Mozambique fought for independence from Portuguese colonial rule. 

Nyusi pursued his education initially in Mozambique, later in Czechoslovakia, where he completed a degree in mechanical engineering at the Military Academy in Brno.  Upon his return to Mozambique, he continued his technical and military training and attended the prestigious Indian Institute of Management in Ahmedabad, India, where he obtained a Master's degree in Management. 

Before entering politics, Filipe Nyusi had a successful career in various state-owned companies, including the state-owned railway company CFM (Caminhos de Ferro de Moçambique) and the national oil and gas company ENH (Empresa Nacional de Hidrocarbonetos).  His professional experiences garnered him recognition and impressed the political leaders of the Frelimo party. 

Filipe Nyusi's political rise began in 2008 when he was appointed Chairman of CFM's Board of Directors.  In 2008, he was also elected to the Central Committee of the Frelimo party.  In 2014, he led the presidential campaign of the Frelimo party and was chosen as its candidate for the presidency.  In October 2014, he won the presidential elections and assumed office as President of Mozambique on January 15, 2015. 

As President, Nyusi has faced challenges such as economic reforms, combating corruption, and addressing armed conflicts with the Renamo guerrilla (Resistência Nacional Moçambicana), the largest opposition party.  He has also had to deal with natural disasters such as Cyclones Idai and Kenneth in 2019, which caused severe destruction and displaced thousands of people. 

Nyusi has also dealt with the rise of Islamist militant groups in the province of Cabo Delgado, his home region, which have been responsible for numerous attacks and a growing humanitarian crisis since 2017. 

Filipe Nyusi was re-elected for a second term in 2019, despite allegations of election manipulation and irregularities raised by the opposition and international observers.  His reelection ensures the continuation of Frelimo rule in Mozambique, a party that has shaped the country's political landscape for almost five decades. 

Nyusi is married and has four children.  As President, he advocates for promoting economic growth, improving the education and healthcare systems, and enhancing regional security.
John Mahama:
John Dramani Mahama was born on November 29, 1958 in Damongo, a small town in the former British colony of Gold Coast.  He is a politician from Ghana who served as the President of Ghana from July 2012 to January 2017. 

Mahama received his early education at Achimota School and later graduated from the Ghana College of Communication with a Bachelor's degree in History.  He then went to the Soviet Union to study at the Institute of Social Sciences (now University of Social Sciences) in Moscow, where he obtained a postgraduate degree in Communication Studies. 

Upon returning to Ghana, Mahama initially worked as a teacher at a secondary school and later entered the communications industry.  He served as the director of a communications company and also worked as a consultant for the Ghanaian Post and Telecommunications Authority. 

John Mahama entered the political scene when he was elected to the Ghanaian Parliament in 1996, representing the Bole Bamboi constituency in northern Ghana.  He served three consecutive terms as a Member of Parliament.  In 2009, he was appointed Vice President by President John Evans Atta Mills. 

As Vice President, Mahama was involved in various areas, including leading programs for economic and political development and overseeing the implementation of infrastructure projects. 

The sudden death of President John Atta Mills in July 2012 led to Mahama being sworn in as President in accordance with the Ghanaian Constitution.  In the December 2012 elections, he ran as the presidential candidate for the National Democratic Congress Party (NDC) and won, earning him his own term as President. 

During his presidency, Mahama focused on improving infrastructure, particularly in the areas of energy, road construction, and healthcare.  Agriculture and education were also priorities of his government.  However, his term was also marked by economic challenges, including high inflation and a weak currency. 

In 2016, Mahama ran for a second term but was defeated by Nana Akufo-Addo of the New Patriotic Party (NPP).  After his presidency, Mahama temporarily stepped out of the spotlight but remained active in the NDC and ran again as their candidate in the 2020 elections, where he once again lost to Akufo-Addo. 

Apart from politics, Mahama is also an author and has written a book titled "My First Coup d'Etat," which includes personal stories and political essays.  He is married to Lordina Mahama, and the couple has five children. 

Please note that this information is based on the knowledge up to my last update in 2023, and the political status of John Mahama may change over time.
Hery Rajaonarimampianina:
Hery Rajaonarimampianina is a politician from Madagascar who served as President of the Indian Ocean island nation from 2014 to 2018.  Born on November 6, 1958 in Antananarivo, Madagascar, Rajaonarimampianina completed his primary and secondary education in his home country before pursuing higher studies. 

He left Madagascar to study in Canada, where he obtained a degree in Economics from the Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières.  After his studies, Rajaonarimampianina returned to his homeland and started a career in business and finance.  He held various positions in the Malagasy private sector, including in the financial and banking sector. 

Following his work in the private sector, Rajaonarimampianina entered politics.  In 2009, he was appointed as Minister of Finance in the government of transitional President Andry Rajoelina, who had taken power after a political crisis and the ousting of then President Marc Ravalomanana.  As Minister of Finance, Rajaonarimampianina had the challenging task of stabilizing Madagascar's economy amid political instability and rebuilding international relations. 

In 2013, Rajaonarimampianina ran for the presidency.  He was elected President of Madagascar on January 25, 2014, in an election that was welcomed by some international observers as a step towards restoring democracy in the country.  His presidency focused on restoring political stability, promoting economic development, and collaborating with international partners. 

During his term in office, Rajaonarimampianina implemented reforms to boost the economy and attract foreign investments.  He also emphasized the importance of environmental protection and worked towards preserving Madagascar's unique biodiversity. 

He also tried to bridge political divides in the country and lay the foundations for sustainable development.  However, his presidency was not without criticism, particularly regarding allegations of corruption, authoritarianism, and lack of progress in combating poverty and social inequalities. 

In November 2019, he ran for a second term but lost to Andry Rajoelina, a former political rival who had previously served as transitional President.  After the end of his presidency, Rajaonarimampianina largely withdrew from the public eye and left the political stage to other actors. 

As of my knowledge as of March 2023, the political career of Hery Rajaonarimampianina encompasses these key elements, but as with any biography, especially in the field of politics, new developments may arise that could expand or require a reinterpretation of his legacy at a later date.
Paul Biya:
Paul Biya, born on February 13, 1933 in Mvomeka’a, Southern Cameroon, is a Cameroonian politician and has been the President of Cameroon since November 6, 1982, making him one of the longest-serving heads of state in the world. 

Biography Overview:

**Early Life and Education:**
Paul Biya was born as the son of Etienne Mvondo Assam and Anastasie Eyenga Elle in a Catholic family.  He initially attended primary and secondary schools in Cameroon.  He continued his education in France, studying at the Sorbonne and Sciences Po.  He obtained degrees in Public Law and Diplomacy from these institutions. 

**Political Beginnings:**
Upon his return to Cameroon in 1962, Biya entered the public service.  His career in the government apparatus quickly gained momentum.  Under President Ahmadou Ahidjo, Biya was appointed as Director of the President's Cabinet before taking on various ministerial positions, including the position of Secretary-General at the Presidency and Prime Minister in 1975. 

**Presidency:**
Following Ahmadou Ahidjo's resignation, Paul Biya was appointed President of Cameroon on November 6, 1982.  He quickly consolidated his power by taking control of the ruling Cameroonian National Union (Union Nationale Camerounaise - UNC), which later evolved into the Cameroon People's Democratic Movement (Rassemblement Démocratique du Peuple Camerounais - RDPC). 

His tenure has been marked by efforts to stabilize the economy and implement political reforms.  The 1990s saw a liberalization of the political system, with Biya allowing multi-party elections, although under conditions that were criticized as undemocratic and favoring his own reelection. 

**Criticism and Controversies:**
Biya's rule has not been without controversies.  There were allegations of electoral fraud, corruption, human rights abuses, and autocracy.  Biya was also criticized for spending long periods abroad.  Additionally, under his government, the conflict with armed separatist groups in the English-speaking regions of Cameroon has escalated, leading to a serious humanitarian crisis. 

**Personal Life:**
Biya married Chantal Biya in 1994, and he has three children from a previous marriage.  As President, he enjoys a high degree of ceremonial status and has a strong focus on state ceremonies and diplomatic affairs. 

**Legacy:**
Paul Biya has a mixed legacy.  While some praise him as a stabilizing force who brought peace and relative stability to Cameroon, others criticize him for authoritarian governance that undermines democracy and hinders the country's development. 

Despite the criticism and challenges to his power base, Biya remains a key figure in the history of Cameroon and Africa, with a political influence that extends well over three decades.
Alassane Ouattara:
Alassane Ouattara is an Ivorian economist and politician who has been the President of Côte d'Ivoire (Ivory Coast) since 2010.  He was born on January 1, 1942, in Dimbokro, French West Africa (now Ivory Coast), and grew up in a Muslim family. 

Ouattara studied in the United States and the United Kingdom, earning a bachelor's degree in economics from Drexel University in Philadelphia, and a master's and Ph. D.  in economics from the University of Pennsylvania. 

Before entering Ivorian politics, Ouattara had an impressive international career.  He worked for the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the Central Bank of West African States (BCEAO).  At the IMF, he rose to the position of Deputy Managing Director, a high position that solidified his reputation as a competent economic expert. 

In the early 1990s, Ouattara returned to Ivory Coast and served as Prime Minister under President Félix Houphouët-Boigny from November 1990 to December 1993.  After the death of Houphouët-Boigny, Ouattara attempted to run for president in the elections but was excluded from several elections due to controversies surrounding his nationality – a politically charged issue in Ivory Coast. 

Ouattara was eventually allowed to run and won the presidential elections in 2010 with the support of the Democratic Party of Côte d'Ivoire (PDCI) and other groups.  However, the elections led to a severe political crisis as the incumbent President Laurent Gbagbo refused to recognize the election results.  After months of tension and violent clashes, the international community finally intervened, and Ouattara officially assumed the presidency. 

During his term in office, Ouattara focused on economic development and reconciliation following the civil war.  He was reelected for a second term in 2015.  However, his presidency has also been marked by controversies and allegations of authoritarianism and suppression of political opponents. 

Despite his initial promise not to run for a third term, Ouattara announced his candidacy for the 2020 presidential elections, leading to political tensions and protests.  He won the elections under controversial circumstances, after the main opposition leaders either were disqualified or called for a boycott. 

Alassane Ouattara remains a polarizing figure in Ivory Coast, recognized for his economic reforms but also criticized for his political style and the restriction of political competition.  His leadership is celebrated for restoring political stability in Ivory Coast but also questioned for the ongoing social and political challenges.
Mahamadou Issoufou:
Mahamadou Issoufou is a Nigerien politician and was the President of Niger from 2011 to 2021.  Born on January 7, 1952, in Dandaji, a village in the Tahoua region, he has played a significant role in his country's politics throughout his life. 

Issoufou completed his primary and secondary education in Niger and then went to France to study at the École des Mines de Saint-Etienne, a prestigious engineering school.  After graduating as a mining engineer, he returned to Niger where he worked for the state mining company SOMAIR. 

His political involvement began in the 1970s during his studies in France when he joined socialist student movements.  Upon his return to Niger, he advocated for democracy and social justice in a country that had suffered for many years under one-party rule and later military dictatorships. 

In 1990, Issoufou was one of the founders of the "Party for Democracy and Socialism" (Parti Nigerien pour la Democratie et le Socialisme, PNDS-Tarayya), which quickly became a leading opposition force against the then ruling military regime.  He was elected party chairman multiple times and was instrumental in building a stable party structure. 

After Niger transitioned to a multi-party system in 1993, Issoufou was elected Prime Minister but could only stay in office until 1994 when a coalition pushed him out of power.  In the following years, he remained a prominent voice in the opposition and ran for the presidency several times. 

In 2011, following a political crisis and a transitional government resulting from a military coup in 2010, Mahamadou Issoufou was democratically elected as President of Niger.  His political program focused on developing the economy, improving the living conditions of the Nigerien population, and combating terrorism and organized crime in the Sahel region. 

During his presidency, Niger faced many challenges, including security threats from Islamist groups in the Sahel, chronic poverty, and climate risks leading to food insecurity.  Despite these difficulties, his government worked to improve infrastructure, promote education, and attract foreign investments. 

Mahamadou Issoufou was re-elected for a second and final term in 2016 and received recognition for his efforts to strengthen democratic institutions and peacefully and orderly step down from office, which was not a given in Niger's history and the wider region. 

In 2020, Issoufou announced that he would not run for re-election according to the constitution after serving two terms, which was a testament to his respect for democratic institutions and processes.  His successor was his party colleague Mohamed Bazoum.  Issoufou was awarded the Ibrahim Prize for African Leadership in 2020 for his role in promoting democracy and economic development in Niger.
Michel Kafando:
Michel Kafando is a Burkinabe diplomat and politician who is best known as the transitional president of Burkina Faso from 2014 to 2015.  He was born on August 18, 1942, in Ouagadougou, the capital of Burkina Faso.  His career includes extensive experience in international diplomacy as well as in the administration of his home country. 

Biographical milestones:

- Early life: Michel Kafando grew up in Ouagadougou and received his early education there.  His academic pursuits took him to France, where he studied at the University of Bordeaux.  He obtained a degree in public law and later earned a doctorate in political science. 

- Diplomatic career: Kafando began his diplomatic career in 1972 and held several positions over the years, including representing Burkina Faso at the United Nations (UN).  He served as his country's ambassador to the UN in New York from 1998 to 2011, playing a key role in promoting Burkina Faso's interests on the international stage. 

- Transitional president: Following the resignation of President Blaise Compaoré in October 2014, who had been in power for 27 years, Kafando was chosen as an impartial candidate to lead Burkina Faso through a transitional phase.  His appointment came after massive public protests against Compaoré's attempt to amend the constitution to stay in power. 

- Term as transitional president: Kafando served as transitional president from November 18, 2014, to December 29, 2015.  In this role, he was tasked with stabilizing the country and organizing free and fair elections.  He led a transitional government composed of civilian and military members, and his tenure was widely regarded as successful, overseeing elections that led to a peaceful transfer of power. 

- After his term: After leaving the presidency, Kafando continued to play a role in Burkina Faso's public life and due to his experience and reputation as a capable mediator in international diplomacy. 

Michel Kafando's contribution to the peaceful transition in Burkina Faso is considered a significant moment in the country's history, and he is seen as a figure who played an important role in the transition to a more democratic government.
Ibrahim Boubacar Ke\u00efta:
Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta, often referred to as IBK, was a Malian politician who served as the President of Mali from September 2013 until his resignation in August 2020. 

Born on January 29, 1945 in Koutiala, then French Sudan (now Mali), he grew up in a relatively privileged family.  He studied abroad, including in France, where he obtained degrees in Political Science and International Relations, also attending the Paris Institute of Political Studies (Sciences Po). 

After his studies, he returned to Mali to start a career in public service.  He initially worked as a technical advisor for the European Development Fund in Brussels and later held various advisory roles for the Malian government. 

His political career began in the 1990s after the overthrow of the long-standing dictator Moussa Traoré, as Mali underwent a democratic transition.  Keïta became a member of the first democratically elected parliament and served as an ambassador as well as in various ministerial positions. 

From 1994 to 2000, he was the President of the National Assembly, and in 2002, he ran for the presidency for the first time, but lost to Amadou Toumani Touré.  Keïta founded the political party "Rassemblement pour le Mali" (RPM) in 2001, which supported him in subsequent election campaigns. 

He ran for the highest office in the state again in 2008 and 2013 and eventually won the presidential elections in 2013, after the country went through a severe political and security crisis that was part of the conflict in northern Mali. 

As President, Keïta faced numerous challenges, including domestic tensions, economic difficulties, and a persistent Islamist-separatist insurgency in the north of the country.  His tenure was also marred by allegations of corruption and a controversial handling of the security situation. 

Discontent with his leadership culminated in mass protests in 2020.  Following a disputed parliamentary election and ongoing demonstrations across the country, Keïta was overthrown in August of the same year through a military coup. 

He was initially arrested and later detained under suspicion before being released in 2021.  Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta then passed away on January 16, 2022 at the age of 76.
Barack Obama:
Barack Obama is an American politician and statesman who served as the 44th President of the United States of America, holding office from 2009 to 2017.  He is a member of the Democratic Party and is known for being the first African-American President of the United States. 

Born on August 4, 1961 in Honolulu, Hawaii, Obama is the son of Stanley Ann Dunham, a white American from Kansas, and Barack Obama Sr. , a black Kenyan.  Obama's parents separated when he was a young boy, and his mother later remarried, this time to a man from Indonesia, leading the family to move to Jakarta.  Obama later returned to Hawaii to live with his grandparents and attend the prestigious Punahou School. 

After graduating, Obama moved to the mainland to study at Occidental College in Los Angeles before transferring to Columbia University in New York City, where he earned his Bachelor's degree in Political Science in 1983.  Following Columbia, he worked in New York for a while before moving to Chicago to work as a community organizer.  In Chicago, he particularly helped in poor black communities that were heavily affected by steel mill closures. 

Determined to enhance his ability to bring about change, he attended Harvard Law School, graduating in 1991.  During his time at Harvard, he was elected as the first African-American president of the Harvard Law Review, gaining nationwide attention.  After Harvard, Obama returned to Chicago and worked as a civil rights attorney and taught constitutional law at the University of Chicago Law School. 

Obama's political career began in 1996 when he was elected to the Illinois Senate, where he served three terms from 1997 to 2004.  During his time in the state senate, he worked on a variety of issues including healthcare reforms, ethics, and early childhood education. 

In 2004, Obama gained national prominence with his passionate keynote address at the Democratic National Convention.  Later that year, he was elected to the U. S.  Senate, where he served from 2005 to 2008.  During his brief time in the Senate, he focused on issues such as controlling weapons of mass destruction and supporting veterans. 

Obama announced his candidacy for the presidency early in 2007.  After a fiercely contested primary campaign against Hillary Clinton, he secured the Democratic Party's nomination.  He ran against Republican candidate John McCain and won the election in 2008.  His presidency was marked by historic efforts including the enactment of healthcare reform known as "Obamacare," overcoming the Great Recession, and initiating key climate protection measures.  Internationally, Obama focused on withdrawing troops from Iraq, the killing of Osama bin Laden, and reaching a nuclear agreement with Iran. 

Following his successful re-election in 2012, he continued his efforts in domestic and foreign policy.  He is also known for his rhetoric and pursuit of comprehensive immigration reform, same-sex marriage, and stricter gun control measures. 

After his presidency ended in January 2017, Obama remained publicly active, advocating for political issues and supporting Democratic Party candidates.  He has also published several books, including "Dreams from My Father" and "The Audacity of Hope," both outlining his philosophical and political views.  His latest work, "A Promised Land," published in 2020, is the first of two planned volumes of his presidential memoirs. 

Barack Obama is married to Michelle Obama, who served as First Lady during his presidency.  The couple has two daughters, Malia and Sasha.  The Obamas continue to be involved in various philanthropic and social projects through their Obama Foundation.
Dilma Rousseff:
Dilma Vana Rousseff was born on December 14, 1947 in Belo Horizonte, Brazil.  She is a Brazilian politician and economist and served as the 36th President of Brazil from 2011 to 2016.  She was the first woman to hold this office in the country's history. 

Rousseff's early life was marked by political activism.  Her father was a Bulgarian immigrant and her mother was of Brazilian descent.  She grew up in a middle-class family and in her youth was politically active against the military dictatorship that ruled Brazil from 1964 to 1985.  During her time as a student, she joined a Marxist urban guerrilla organization that opposed the dictatorship.  In 1970, she was arrested and interrogated under torture before being released after nearly three years in prison. 

After her release, Rousseff continued her education and earned a degree in Economics from the University of Campinas.  She worked as an economic adviser in various government agencies and took part in important energy projects. 

Her political career began in the 1980s when she joined the Democratic Labour Party (PDT).  In the 1990s, she switched to the Workers' Party (PT), where she became a prominent figure.  Rousseff served in various positions, including the Ministry of Energy in Rio Grande do Sul and later as the Minister of Mines and Energy during the presidency of Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. 

She built a reputation as a competent manager and technocratic expert and was appointed Minister of the President's Office in 2005, where she acted as a sort of Prime Minister.  With the support of President Lula, she was positioned as his successor and won the presidential elections in 2010. 

As President, she continued poverty alleviation programs that had started under Lula and introduced initiatives for education and healthcare.  However, her government faced several challenges, including economic downturn, public protests against corruption and mismanagement, and political struggles. 

In 2016, Rousseff faced impeachment proceedings triggered by allegations that she manipulated government accounts to secure her re-election in 2014 – a process her opponents called "fiscal pedaling. " Despite her assurances of having done nothing wrong, she was removed from office by Congress; her Vice President Michel Temer assumed the presidency. 

Rousseff remains a polarizing figure in the Brazilian political spectrum, with strong supporters and opponents.  Following her impeachment, she continues to be active in politics and public discourse.  Her tenure is still being studied and evaluated by historians and political analysts due to her historic role as the first female president and her efforts in social programs, as well as the controversial impeachment process that plunged the country into a deep political crisis.
Enrique Pe\u00f1a Nieto:
Enrique Peña Nieto is a Mexican politician and lawyer who served as the 57th President of Mexico from 2012 to 2018.  He was born on July 20, 1966 in Atlacomulco, a town in the State of Mexico.  Peña Nieto is a member of the Institutional Revolutionary Party (Partido Revolucionario Institucional, PRI), a political party that dominated Mexico for much of the 20th century. 

Peña Nieto completed his law degree at the Universidad Panamericana and obtained a master's degree in Business Administration from the ITESM (Instituto Tecnológico y de Estudios Superiores de Monterrey). 

His political career began in various positions at the local level in the State of Mexico.  Peña Nieto served as Undersecretary in his state's Ministry of the Interior and as a deputy in the local parliament.  His rapid political ascent was favored by his connections and his membership in the PRI. 

In 2005, he was elected Governor of the State of Mexico.  During his term from 2005 to 2011, he initiated various infrastructure and social programs, although controversies, including allegations of corruption and lack of transparency, still shadowed his administration. 

Peña Nieto ran for the presidency of Mexico in 2012.  He won the election and took office on December 1, 2012, succeeding Felipe Calderón.  His presidency was characterized by efforts to implement structural reforms, including in the education, energy, and telecommunications sectors, aimed at fostering growth and competition in the Mexican economy. 

However, his term was also marred by scandals and issues.  The so-called "Casa Blanca scandal," involving a luxurious house acquired by Peña Nieto's wife from a state contractor, drew criticism and led to a significant loss of credibility.  Additionally, his government faced serious human rights violations, including the disappearance of 43 students from Ayotzinapa in 2014, which sparked international outrage. 

The economic performance during his presidency was mixed, and despite some progress in the economy, there were criticisms regarding inequality, poverty, and security issues.  Violence in Mexico, particularly related to drug cartels, remained an unresolved problem during his presidency. 

After his term ended in 2018, Peña Nieto largely withdrew from public life.  His political legacy remains controversial, as he is remembered for both implementing key reforms and being involved in corruption scandals and security failures. 

Please note that this information is current as of my knowledge cut-off date, and there may have been developments since that time.
Juan Manuel Santos:
Juan Manuel Santos Calderón, born on August 10, 1951 in Bogotá, Colombia, is a Colombian politician, statesman, and member of an influential family in Colombia.  He served as the 32nd President of Colombia from 2010 to 2018 and was internationally recognized for his efforts to end the decades-long conflict with the FARC (Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia), including receiving the Nobel Peace Prize in 2016. 

Education and early career:
Santos comes from a wealthy and influential family and is the great-nephew of former Colombian President Eduardo Santos.  He studied at the University of Kansas, earning a degree in Economics and Business Administration.  He later obtained a Master's in Economics from the London School of Economics and a Master's in Public Administration from Harvard University. 

His professional career began in the media industry as deputy director of the news magazine El Tiempo, founded by his family.  He held several government positions, including Minister of Foreign Trade, Minister of Finance, and ultimately Minister of Defense under President Álvaro Uribe, before deciding to run for the presidency. 

Presidency:
Santos was elected President of Colombia in 2010, succeeding Uribe.  During his first term, he focused on security in the country and combating drug trafficking, while also continuing the previous administration's policy of dialogue with the FARC. 

However, the greatest achievement of his presidency was the peace process with the FARC.  After four years of negotiations, Santos signed a peace agreement with the guerrilla group in 2016, largely ending the civil war that had lasted over half a century and claimed over 220,000 lives.  The agreement was initially rejected in a popular vote, but was approved after further negotiations and modifications by the Colombian parliament. 

For his role in bringing peace to Colombia, Santos received the Nobel Peace Prize in 2016.  This was a significant international recognition and underscored the significance of the peace process for the country and the entire region. 

Life after the presidency:
After leaving the presidency in 2018, Santos remained active in the field of international relations and peace consolidation.  He took up a professorship at Harvard University and is also involved in various international organizations dealing with global challenges such as conflict resolution, climate change, and sustainable development. 

Despite criticism of some aspects of his presidency, particularly regarding economic issues and the implementation of the peace agreement, Juan Manuel Santos remains a key figure in Colombian and international politics, whose legacy is particularly defined by his efforts towards the Colombian peace process.
Cristina Fern\u00e1ndez de Kirchner:
Cristina Fernández de Kirchner is an Argentine politician and lawyer who served as President of Argentina and is a key figure in Argentine and Latin American politics.  She was born on February 19, 1953, in La Plata, Province of Buenos Aires, as Cristina Elisabet Fernández. 

Education and early career:
Cristina Fernández began her law studies at the National University of La Plata, where she met her future husband, Néstor Kirchner.  After graduating, they opened a joint law firm in their hometown of Río Gallegos, Province of Santa Cruz. 

Political career:
Cristina Fernández began her political career in the 1980s.  She was a deputy in the Province of Santa Cruz and later also at the national level.  She strengthened her political influence as a senator and as a deputy before becoming First Lady in 2003 when Néstor Kirchner assumed the presidency of Argentina. 

Néstor Kirchner's presidency:
During his presidency, Cristina Kirchner was an active First Lady and supported Néstor Kirchner in various social and political projects.  Néstor Kirchner's government was characterized by a strong left-wing ideology focusing on social programs and the recovery of the Argentine economy after the 2001 economic crisis. 

Presidency:
After the end of Néstor Kirchner's term, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner successfully ran for the presidency and was sworn in as the first directly elected female president of Argentina in 2007.  During her tenure, she advocated for issues such as human rights, gender equality, and the expansion of state intervention in the economy. 

Her presidency was also marked by controversies, including allegations of corruption, conflicts with the agricultural industry, and the independent press.  Nevertheless, she managed to retain the support of a significant portion of the population, partly thanks to popular social programs and her charismatic personality. 

Cristina Fernández de Kirchner was re-elected for a second term in 2011.  Her second term lasted until 2015 and continued to be a time of political tensions, particularly regarding economic policy and foreign relations. 

Post-presidency:
After her presidency, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner remained a prominent figure in Argentine politics.  Her political legacy and that of her husband live on in the Frente para la Victoria (Front for Victory) party, a faction of Peronist Justicialism. 

In 2017, she returned to politics as a senator.  Her role in the Senate focused on opposing the policies of her successor, Mauricio Macri.  Cristina Kirchner continues to face various legal investigations related to allegations of corruption during her time in office. 

In 2019, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner was elected Vice President and assumed office alongside President Alberto Fernández, highlighting her enduring significance in Argentine politics. 

Cristina Fernández de Kirchner's life and career are characteristic of the turbulent political currents in Argentina and Latin America.  She is a polarizing figure – celebrated both as a symbol of progress and social inclusion and criticized as an embodiment of political scandals and mismanagement.
Justin Trudeau:
Justin Trudeau is a Canadian politician and has been the 23rd Prime Minister of Canada since November 4, 2015.  He is the leader of the Liberal Party of Canada and a Member of Parliament for the Papineau riding in Montreal. 

Born on December 25, 1971 in Ottawa, Justin Trudeau is the eldest son of former Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and his wife Margaret.  Because of this, Justin grew up in the public eye and developed an early understanding of politics and public life.  He received a comprehensive education, taking him from Canadian elite institutions to earning a bachelor's degree at McGill University in Montreal, and later studying engineering and environmental geography at the University of British Columbia. 

After completing his bachelor's degree in Literature at McGill University, Trudeau continued his education and obtained a Bachelor of Education at the University of British Columbia.  Before entering politics, Trudeau worked as a teacher in Vancouver, teaching French and mathematics at a public high school. 

Following in his father's political footsteps, Justin Trudeau decided to run for the Papineau riding in 2008 and was elected, defeating the incumbent from the Bloc Québécois party.  He expanded his profile within the party, focusing on issues such as education, youth, and the environment. 

After the then-leader Michael Ignatieff resigned in 2011, Trudeau announced his candidacy for the leadership of the Liberal Party.  In April 2013, he won the leadership decisively and led the Liberal Party to a remarkable comeback in the 2015 federal elections.  The Liberals went from the third-largest party in Parliament to a majority government, solidifying Trudeau's status as a charismatic renovator of the party. 

As Prime Minister, Trudeau pursued a policy of social liberalism, focusing on issues such as indigenous rights, gender equality, the legalization of cannabis, and a strong environmental policy.  Additionally, he increased Canada's engagement in international affairs and advocated for multilateralism and free trade. 

Trudeau has also faced challenges and controversies during his tenure, including ethical investigations, the strain on the national economy due to COVID-19, and tensions in the energy policy and pipeline construction sector.  Nevertheless, he managed to retain power for the Liberal Party in the 2019 and 2021 elections, although forming a minority government on both occasions. 

Justin Trudeau is married to Sophie Grégoire Trudeau, a former television and radio host.  The couple has three children.  Trudeau's life story is marked by his dedication to his profession and family, as well as his continuous effort to follow in the footsteps of his famous father while forging his own path in Canada's political landscape.
Ollanta Humala:
Ollanta Moisés Humala Tasso was born on June 27, 1962, in Lima, Peru.  He is a Peruvian former military officer and politician who served as the 65th President of Peru from 2011 to 2016.  His political career is characterized by his left-leaning views and his identification with the political ideologies of ethnonationalism and social inclusionism. 

Origin and Military Career:
Humala is partially of Quechua indigenous descent and comes from a politically active family.  His father, Isaac Humala, is a well-known lawyer and a member of the Peruvian political landscape.  His mother, Elena Tasso, was also politically involved. 

Ollanta Humala pursued a military career and graduated from the Chorrillos Military Academy in Lima.  His career in the Peruvian Armed Forces included various positions, including involvement in the fight against the Maoist guerrilla movement Shining Path, which was responsible for a bloody civil war in Peru in the 1980s and 1990s.  In 2000, he rebelled against the government of Alberto Fujimori together with his brother Antauro but was pardoned when Alejandro Toledo took office. 

Political Career:
After his military career, Humala began his involvement in politics.  In 2005, he founded the Peruvian Nationalist Party, which advocated for state intervention in the economy, poverty reduction, and strengthening national sovereignty. 

Humala ran for president for the first time in 2006 but lost in the runoff against Alan García.  His political profile at that time was heavily influenced by the ideas of Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez, which faced skepticism from the Peruvian middle and upper class. 

Presidency:
In 2011, Humala ran for president again and this time won the election.  During his presidency, he focused on social inclusion, fair distribution of income from Peru's natural resources, and strengthening social infrastructure.  He implemented programs such as "Pension 65," a social program for the elderly, and "Beca 18," a scholarship program for underprivileged students. 

Despite his left-wing political agenda, Humala took a more moderate stance than expected by promoting investments in the mining sector and maintaining macroeconomic stability.  His presidency was also marked by criticism and controversies, including allegations of corruption and human rights violations related to the mining industry. 

After the Presidency:
Following the end of his presidency, Humala and his wife Nadine Heredia were implicated in a corruption scandal involving the Brazilian construction company Odebrecht.  They were provisionally arrested in July 2017 while investigations into money laundering and illegal campaign financing were ongoing.  The arrest was seen as a preventive measure to prevent flight or obstruction of justice. 

As of my knowledge in April 2023, the trial against Humala and his wife was still ongoing, and there have been no final judgments on the allegations. 

Ollanta Humala's political legacy is complex and reflects the tensions in Peruvian politics between leftist social movements and the market economy, ethnic identity issues, and the need for political stability in the context of the country's socioeconomic development.
Nicol\u00e1s Maduro:
Nicolás Maduro is a Venezuelan politician who has been serving as the President of Venezuela since April 19, 2013.  He was born on November 23, 1962 in Caracas, Venezuela, and came from humble beginnings. 

In his youth, Maduro worked as a bus driver and was involved in labor unions.  He became a union leader in the Caracas Metro organization.  He began his political career as a member of the United Socialist Party of Venezuela (PSUV), the party founded by his predecessor and mentor Hugo Chávez. 

Maduro held various positions in Chávez's government.  He served as Minister of Foreign Affairs from 2006 to 2013 and was responsible for shaping Venezuela's foreign policy under Chávez.  In this role, he established relationships with many countries, especially with other left-leaning governments in Latin America, as well as allies such as Russia, China, and Iran. 

After President Chávez passed away on March 5, 2013, Maduro, who had been recently appointed as Chávez's Vice President, was sworn in as interim president in accordance with the Venezuelan constitution.  He won the subsequent presidential elections on April 14, 2013, but only with a narrow victory over his opponent Henrique Capriles Radonski. 

Maduro's presidency has been marked by ongoing political instability, deepening socio-economic crisis, and human rights allegations.  Under his leadership, Venezuela has experienced hyperinflation, widespread shortages of basic goods, and a significant increase in poverty and crime.  Political tensions have escalated since the opposition won the parliamentary elections in December 2015, leading to numerous confrontations with the executive branch. 

During Maduro's presidency, the Venezuelan government has also faced criticism for the erosion of democratic institutions and processes.  Several countries and international organizations have viewed his reelection in 2018 as illegitimate and contested his governance.  The United States and many other nations have supported his rival Juan Guaidó, who declared himself interim president in January 2019. 

Despite domestic and international challenges, Maduro has managed to maintain his power through the support of the military, the Supreme Court, and the National Electoral Council controlled by his supporters, as well as by cracking down on the opposition.  His regime has faced allegations of election fraud, corruption, and human rights violations, leading to sanctions from the United States and the European Union. 

Maduro's leadership remains highly controversial, and the country is facing one of the most severe economic and humanitarian crises in its history.
Michelle Bachelet:
Verónica Michelle Bachelet Jeria is a Chilean politician and physician who served as the first female President of Chile in history from 2006 to 2010 and from 2014 to 2018.  She is also known for her work as the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights. 

Michelle Bachelet was born on September 29, 1951, in Santiago, Chile.  Her father, Alberto Bachelet, was a general in the Chilean Air Force and a supporter of socialist President Salvador Allende.  Her mother, Ángela Jeria, was an archaeologist.  The Bachelet family was politically active and heavily persecuted after the 1973 military coup that led to the dictatorship under General Augusto Pinochet.  Her father was arrested and died in 1974 as a result of torture.  Michelle Bachelet and her mother were also detained and tortured before managing to escape into exile abroad. 

During her exile, Bachelet studied medicine in the German Democratic Republic.  Upon her return to Chile in 1979, she continued her medical studies and specialized in pediatrics and public health. 

Bachelet's political career began after Chile returned to democracy in 1990.  She served in the Health and Defense Ministries under President Ricardo Lagos.  Her competent work and commitment to social justice and gender equality helped her gain broad support.  In 2006, she was elected as the presidential candidate of the center-left coalition Concertación de Partidos por la Democracia. 

Her first presidential term focused on social reforms, including expanding social security systems and improving education.  Despite controversies and challenges during her term, such as student protests over educational reforms, she remained a popular figure. 

After the end of her first term (Chilean presidents cannot be directly re-elected), Bachelet was appointed in 2010 as the first Executive Director of UN Women, a United Nations organization advocating for gender equality and the empowerment of women globally. 

In 2013, Michelle Bachelet returned to Chilean politics and won the presidential election again, implementing significant reforms such as a tax reform to fund educational initiatives and a revision of electoral laws. 

Following her second term as President of Chile, Michelle Bachelet assumed the position of United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights in September 2018, a role she continues to hold today.  In this capacity, she advocates for the promotion and protection of human rights worldwide.  Bachelet's history of overcoming personal adversity and lifelong commitment to justice and equality have made her a prominent figure in international politics.
Otto P\u00e9rez Molina:
Otto Fernando Pérez Molina is a Guatemalan politician and former military officer who served as President of Guatemala from 2012 to 2015.  He was born on December 1, 1950, in Guatemala City and spent most of his career in the military before transitioning into politics. 

Military Career:
Pérez Molina joined the Guatemalan Army in the early 1970s, during a time when the country was plagued by a lengthy and brutal internal armed conflict that lasted from 1960 to 1996.  He graduated from the Polytechnic Institute and rose through the ranks during his military career.  In the 1980s, he served as part of the infamous Kaibiles, a special unit of the Guatemalan military. 

His military career is controversial due to allegations of human rights violations committed during his service.  However, Pérez Molina himself has consistently denied any wrongdoing. 

Political Career:
After the signing of the 1996 Peace Accords that ended the civil war in Guatemala, Pérez Molina entered politics.  He was a founding member of the Patriota Party (Partido Patriota - PP) and later was elected as its leader. 

In 2007, Pérez Molina ran for the presidency for the first time but was defeated in the runoff.  However, he ran again in 2011 and was elected as the President of Guatemala.  His presidency began on January 14, 2012, and was characterized by a tough stance on crime and promises of an "iron fist" (Mano Dura) against crime. 

Presidency and Resignation:
During his presidency, Pérez Molina faced various challenges, including widespread crime, relentless poverty, and corruption in the country.  Despite initial popularity, his term and reputation were overshadowed by several high-profile corruption scandals. 

In 2015, he became embroiled in a major corruption scandal known as "La Línea," which was uncovered through joint investigations by the International Commission against Impunity in Guatemala (Comisión Internacional contra la Impunidad en Guatemala - CICIG) and the Guatemalan Attorney General's Office.  The scandal involved a customs fraud scheme in which officials allegedly accepted bribes to allow lower customs fees. 

Following the revelations, mass protests erupted throughout the country demanding his resignation.  On September 3, 2015, Pérez Molina resigned as President after his parliamentary immunity was revoked, and he was arrested. 

Aftermath:
Following his resignation, Otto Pérez Molina was charged and imprisoned.  His trial for corruption, money laundering, and other crimes began, and he continues to deny all charges.  As of my knowledge (as of 2023), he is still undergoing a legal process, and his final legal fate remains pending. 

Pérez Molina's career reflects the complex realities of Guatemala, a country marked by a violent past, a challenging democratic transition, and ongoing challenges in the areas of rule of law and fighting corruption.
Rafael Correa:
Rafael Correa is an Ecuadorian economist and politician who served as the President of Ecuador from 2007 to 2017.  He was born on April 6, 1963 in Guayaquil, Ecuador, and comes from a middle-class family. 

Education and Academic Career:
After completing his schooling, Correa studied at the Universidad Católica de Santiago de Guayaquil, where he obtained a Bachelor's degree in Economics.  He continued his academic career and earned a Master's degree in Economics from the Catholic University of Leuven in Belgium, followed by another Master's degree in Economics from the University of Illinois in the United States.  In 2001, Correa completed his Ph. D.  in Economics with a focus on growth theory and public finances at the same university. 

Professional Career:
Before his political career, Correa worked as a university professor and lecturer in economic theory in Ecuador, publishing several contributions and studies on economic topics. 

Political Career:
Rafael Correa's political rise began in 2005 when he was appointed Minister of Economy and Finance in the cabinet of then-President Alfredo Palacio.  In this position, he advocated for a socially-oriented economic policy and tried to improve fiscal discipline but resigned in protest against measures he perceived as neoliberal after a few months. 

In 2006, Correa founded the political movement Alianza PAIS and ran for the presidency.  In November 2006, he was elected President of Ecuador following a runoff against entrepreneur Álvaro Noboa. 

Presidency:
During his presidency, Correa implemented a series of reforms known as the "Citizens' Revolution. " He focused on improving infrastructure, education, and healthcare.  He also expanded social programs and strengthened state control over oil and mining resources.  Correa pursued a policy of economic redistribution and aimed for greater economic independence from international influence. 

Correa was also known for renegotiating foreign debts and rejecting certain international loans that he considered illegitimate and unfair to the Ecuadorian people.  His government participated in the founding of the Bank of the South, a financial institution established by South American countries to reduce dependence on traditional Western financial institutions. 

During Correa's presidency, Ecuador also experienced improvements in stability and economic growth.  However, his presidency was also marked by controversies, including allegations of press freedom violations and corruption scandals. 

Post-Presidency:
Since the end of his third and final term in 2017, Rafael Correa has faced political and legal challenges.  He currently resides in Belgium and is involved in several legal proceedings, including a conviction in Ecuador for corruption, which he describes as politically motivated. 

Despite the controversies, Correa remains a polarizing figure in Ecuadorian politics, with a strong following and an equally passionate opposition.  His political legacy is characterized by profound social and political changes in Ecuador as well as a reorientation of Ecuador's foreign policy.
Evo Morales:
Evo Morales, whose full name is Juan Evo Morales Ayma, was born on October 26, 1959 in Isallavi, a small village in the mountainous region of Oruro, Bolivia.  He belongs to the indigenous Aymara ethnic group and is a prominent political leader and former President of Bolivia. 

After leaving school at a young age to work in the fields and help his family, Morales later moved to Chapare in the Cochabamba region to cultivate coca as a farmer.  His political career began in the coca growers' union, where he actively advocated for the rights of coca growers while the Bolivian government, under pressure from the United States, tried to drastically reduce coca production. 

Morales' rise in politics was supported by his fight against the policy of coca eradication and his commitment to the rights of the indigenous population and rural workers.  These issues were central to his political platform when he first won a seat in the Bolivian Congress in 1997. 

In 1998, Morales helped found the Movement for Socialism (Movimiento al Socialismo, MAS), which positioned itself as a left-wing alternative and representative of indigenous peoples and agricultural workers.  Through his leadership in MAS, Morales became a symbolic figure and ran for the presidency in 2002, but narrowly lost. 

In 2005, Morales made history by becoming the first indigenous president of Bolivia.  He won the presidential elections with broad support, especially from poorer sectors and indigenous communities.  As president, Morales implemented a series of progressive reforms, including the nationalization of the oil and gas industry and a land reform aimed at redistributing land to needy indigenous groups. 

He also strongly advocated for the rights of indigenous peoples and was responsible for Bolivia adopting a new constitution in 2009, which significantly strengthened the rights of indigenous communities and recognized the country as a plurinational republic. 

During his presidency (2006-2019), Morales was seen as a key player in the "pink tide" ("Marea Rosa"), a series of left-wing political movements and governments in Latin America that emerged in the 2000s. 

However, his term was also marked by controversies and accusations of power abuse and authoritarianism.  His efforts to run for a fourth term and to lift term limits led to fierce resistance and allegations of violating democratic principles.  In November 2019, Morales resigned after weeks of intense protests and pressure from the military and police.  He initially went into exile in Mexico and later moved to Argentina. 

His political legacy remains divided; he is celebrated both as a champion of the poor and indigenous peoples, and criticized as a controversial leader who wanted to stay in power for too long.  His support base in Bolivia and in other parts of the world remains strong, and his political movement MAS continues to be a major force in Bolivian politics, even after his presidency.
Michel Martelly:
Michel Joseph Martelly, known by the stage name "Sweet Micky," was born on February 12, 1961, in Port-au-Prince, Haiti.  He is a Haitian musician and politician who served as the President of Haiti from 2011 to 2016.  Martelly is known for his lively personality both on stage and in politics, and has elicited both applause and controversy throughout his career. 

Martelly was born into a wealthy family and spent most of his youth in Port-au-Prince.  He began his music career in the late 1980s as a keyboardist in local bands.  Soon, he established himself as a solo artist, and his alter ego "Sweet Micky" became known for his energetic performances and humorous, often provocative music. 

Martelly's music style, Kompa music – a popular Haitian music style originating from a Merengue hybrid, is characterized by its playfulness and free approach to taboo topics.  Throughout his career, he released a number of albums that were popular among fans in Haiti and the Haitian diaspora. 

After many years as a musician, Martelly decided to transition to politics.  He ran as an outsider for the presidency following the devastating 2010 earthquake that hit Haiti hard.  He positioned himself as someone who could challenge and change traditional Haitian politics.  With the support of the youth and his popularity as a musician, he won the elections and became the 56th President of Haiti. 

Martelly took office under difficult circumstances.  Haiti was still recovering from the effects of the earthquake, and the country was struggling with poverty, corruption, and political instability.  During his presidency, Martelly focused on rebuilding infrastructure, developing tourism, and implementing educational reforms.  However, his time in office was marked by political unrest and allegations of authoritarianism and corruption. 

Martelly's presidency ended without a direct successor, as the 2015 elections were marred by irregularities and resulting protests led to a crisis.  Martelly's succession was handled through interim agreements until his successor, Jovenel Moïse, was elected. 

After the end of his presidency, Martelly partially returned to music and performed at various events.  However, his political legacy remains controversial in Haiti, and the criticisms that arose during his term continue to raise questions about his leadership and handling of the country's challenges.  Despite mixed feelings, he remains an influential figure in Haiti's social and political landscape.
Ra\u00fal Castro:
Raúl Modesto Castro Ruz is a Cuban revolutionary and politician who served as President of the State Council and the Council of Ministers of Cuba from 2008 to 2018.
